body:
<!--
**PLEASE READ THIS FIRST:**
- Do not use the bug and feature tracker for support requests. Use the `cython-users` mailing list instead.
- Did you search for similar issues already? Please do, it helps to save us precious time that we otherwise could not invest into development.
- Did you try the latest master branch or pre-release? It might already have what you want to report. Also see the [Changelog](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/CHANGES.rst) regarding recent changes.
-->

**Describe the bug**
When declaring a cpdef enum, its values are also dumped into the module namespace and made accessible from Python. This isn't how normal Python enums work. I also want to avoide cluttering up the modules namespace.
**To Reproduce**
```cython
cpdef enum letters:
	a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i,j
```
Compile the code, load the extension module from Python and do "module.a"


**Expected behavior**
All enum values are stored inside the enum (for example letters.a) but not available in the module.
**Environment (please complete the following information):**
Os: Windows 10 (64-bit)
Python: 3.9.5
Cython: 0.29.26

**Additional context**

comment_data.body: Hmm. Interesting. No-one ever complained about this. It's how C enums work, and `cpdef enum` defines a C enum (`cdef enum`) and makes it _additionally_ available to Python. Whether that means that it literally has to appear like the C enum – I don't know.

I don't mind that the enums values are globally available from Cython code, but Python can already access them via the enum class.
Actually there's a project that migrated from cpdef enums to pure Python enums partially for this reason, [https://github.com/synthizer/synthizer/commit/e45c22803b01ca4f96864b305f1072b31fccc64e](https://github.com/synthizer/synthizer/commit/e45c22803b01ca4f96864b305f1072b31fccc64e)

@Keithcat1 @scoder 

I have exactly the same request.

> ... No-one ever complained about this. It's how C enums work, and cpdef enum defines a C enum (cdef enum) and makes it additionally available to Python. Whether that means that it literally has to appear like the C enum – I don't know.

It would make sense if it didn't, since that already is the [expected behavior of python enums](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44027343/python-how-to-pollute-namespace-with-enum-values). The C behavior of all enums in the global namespace makes little sense in Python which prefers things nicely namespaced. 

This issue becomes readily apparent if you have a ton of enums and it quickly becomes confusing for users used to namespace-helping code-completion.
We've also moved away from cpdef enum for the same reason. The pollution to the module namespace is too much from the tab completion perspective.

Given that we allow both 
```cython
cpdef enum:
    A, B, C
```
and
```cython
cpdef enum ANamedEnum:
   X, Y, Z
```
it seems reasonable to distinguish between the two so that the first produces global names for the enum values and the second namespaces them in `ANamedEnum`.

Well, currently, this is not how it works and all enum values behave like C enum values in that they become defined globally. I agree that that's counter-intuitive from a Python point of view. Namespaces are one honking great idea, after all.

For users, the work to remove these names from the module namespace is rather more than for adding them to the module namespace if they want. Removing probably requires a loop (and a spelled out list for anonymous enums), whereas adding is quite easy by updating `globals()`.

Thus, we could take the general cleanup that users of Cython 3.1 probably want to apply to their code base as an opportunity to change the behaviour of named cpdef enums and keeping them namespaced by default. Users who really want the global names could then add this after the enum:
```python
globals().update(MyNamedEnum.__members__)
```
This is also backwards compatible because it would simply overwrite the existing names with themselves in older Cython versions.

@da-woods @matusvalo @robertwb what do you think?

The question is always "how much code will it break?". I suspect in this case it's a bit, but it's breakage that's reasonably easy for users to work around.

A couple of other notes:
* for c++ `enum class` enums we already don't place the names in the global scope (because c++ doesn't). I don't think that changes what we want to do in general though.
* Is there a difference between `extern` and non-extern enums? In that `extern` ones are matching what C does, and non-extern ones are a Cython creation? I don't think there should be necessarily.
* Do we need to change the lookup of names within Cython (where I think you'd find the C name at global scope) or just the names that are put in the module dictionary?

Here's a PR. Let's discuss if we want this change in behaviour.

https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6382

It will probably break existing code and/or tests. It seems just too easy to use enum names without their namespace prefix, intended or not. And fixing tests tends to be more work than fixing the implementation.

Upside is that adapting the code is backwards compatible since the prefixed enum names always worked.

I like the change. I agree that keeping C behavior only for C and Python version should work as namespace. Two points:
1. We need to document it better
2. We need to provide somewhere (changelog?) how to implement backward compatible version of enum (as mentioned here: https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4571#issuecomment-2324250670)
3. Maybe if there will be request from users having problem with migrating to have compilation directive enabling old behaviour.

rename.from: [BUG] declaring a cpdef enum also populates the module namespace
rename.to: [ENH] Allow moving named cpdef enum values into the

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.7.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: [BUG] Declaring a named cpdef enum also populates the module namespace
